utterances: Yeah.
There are six pre-selected candidates here in Iran, and his two main competitors are both conservatives.
As I said, they're both in the city Mashhad.
The first one is currently the mayor of Tehran, airline pilot, former police commander Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf.
And he says that he can create 5 million extra jobs.
Then there's the other candidate, and he is the most outspoken hardline candidate, a man who wants to make Iran self-sufficient.
This is a cleric called Ebrahim Raisi.
You know, one of the criticisms, as you mentioned, that has been leveled at President Rouhani is that he swept into office, he promised economic reform.
Are you able to paint us any kind of picture of the quality of life of whether sanctions relief has actually helped people's lives improve?
Well, I was just talking to two young guys at the coffee shop, and they were both between 20 and 25 years old.
For those two guys, President Rouhani hasn't delivered.
They're either out of work or they will be out of work.
What President Rouhani is saying to these people is that, wait, give me time.
Well, of course, for two students here on the streets of Mashhad, that is a world away.
They want to see change right now.
One question that will be very much on the mind of Americans following elections in Tehran is, of course, the nuclear deal which came into being under President Rouhani's tenure.
Will that stay in place no matter who wins?
I think it's very much in the Iranian establishment's interest to keep the nuclear deal in place.
The Iranians know that if they have to return to a time of sanctions, it will be detrimental to their economy.
So no matter who becomes Iran's next president, they will try and keep this nuclear agreement.
And, of course, we must be honest, it wasn't President Rouhani who created this nuclear deal in Iran.
You can't make big decisions without the supreme leader signing off on it.
So in the end, this is a decision by the highest power in Iran.
Is that what Iranians will be voting on or is it, like, just about everywhere on Earth that people are voting based on how they feel this might shake down into their ordinary life?
It actually shows how Iran over the decades has become a less ideological and more normal country because it's not ideology.
It is the economy (unintelligible).
And if you go to Tehran or to Mashhad or to the smaller city here in Iran, people will tell you I want life to improve for me, for my family.
I want to send my children to school.
I want to have a pension.
They're not that much different from the rest of the world.
That's Thomas Erdbrink.
He is the Tehran bureau chief for The New York Times, and he joined us via Skype from Mashhad in the north of Iran.
Thomas Erdbrink, thank you.
Thank you.
A blues legend was laid to rest in Southaven, Mississippi, this week.
Milton Campbell, better known as Little Milton, was a legend of the Delta blues, a self-taught guitarist with a voice that really made you believe what he had to say.
(Soundbite of ""Grits Ain't Groceries"")
(Singing) If I don't love you, baby, grits ain't grocery, eggs ain't poultry and Mona Lisa was a man.
Oh, yeah!
Let's get into it!
Listen!
That's ""Grits Ain't Groceries"" from 1969.
Little Milton died of a brain aneurysm at the Delta Medical Center in Memphis this week.
He was 70, but still touring and recording music.
His most recent album was this year's ""Think of Me.
Isaac Hayes was at Little Milton's bedside and attended the funeral.
He joins us from Memphis.
Mr.
Hayes, thanks so much for being with us.
How ya doin', Scooter?
I'm fine.
Thank you, sir.
Just fine.
What was Little Milton like?
What do you remember?
Well, you know, I remember long before I met him, I was a fan.

He was around Memphis, Tennessee, when I was doing my early, early years--you know, doing the Chitlin Circuit gigs and stuff--and I heard his recordings, and every--nobody said anything negative about Milton.
Milton was always a gentleman and he was--he had smarts about him.
He had business sense.
And, of course, his talent--you know, it goes without saying.
He was a writer; he was a musician; he was a singer.
He was all of that put together--what a lot of us wanted to be.
And when I had the pleasure of meeting him...
Yeah.
...he was always--he was not snobbish.
He was very warm, kind of quiet at times.
Came out of a juke joint one time and just--Milton was standing outside like he was meditating.
He just impressed me as a very serious man, but he was a lot of fun, too.
When I first heard that Milton had been stricken, I went to his bedside.
Yeah.
And, you know, I talked to him, you know.
A lot of times that helps.
And I just told him how I felt about him, and, man, you got to get him to--get him out of his bed--You know?...
Yeah.
...and things like that.
And, of course, you know, God over all, he had a better--another plan.
He plucked that flower.
Yeah.
But he did his tour here on Earth, and like they said at his funeral, he's up in heaven now with Albert King and those guys.
You know, a brother said, `Luther's probably doing his vocalizing up there.
You know?
Yeah.
May I ask what the funeral was like this week?
Well, it is not easy to figure out what's going on there.
It is a complicated process and there is at the moment a debate about who won the delegates from yesterday's contest.
The Obama campaign says they've won.
The Clinton folks say they won.
These are in the pledged delegates assigned by the voting.
This is a separate question from the superdelegates, who are the party functionaries who get special - a special vote at the convention.
But the take away from all of this is that they are essentially tied on the question of delegates.
And so like everything in this Democratic race, it is very, very close.
John, back to the Republicans.
Senator McCain - writing about his campaign yesterday, the headline for your piece was Can He Hold It Together?
And you were talking about his split with conservative voters.
So can he?
He seems to have gotten a big boost in that regard yesterday.
What they were quite worried about is that this onslaught from the conservative commentariate - which was essentially saying back Romney, forget about Huckabee - would start to have some purchase.
And it didn't, particularly in California, where the McCain campaign was very concerned going into the primary.
They ended up beating Romney pretty handily.
And in those southern states, the core ideological base for the Republican Party, that ended up - all those votes ended up going to Mike Huckabee and not to Romney.
In some cases Romney came in third in those southern states.
So for the moment it looks like McCain is okay.
The question now is if he gets to the general election, what shape will his base be in.
And that may depend on who the Democratic nominee is.
Clearly the base will be more energized if it's Hillary Clinton.
If it's Barack Obama, that might make things tougher for McCain or any Republican nominee.
Madeleine's got an interview coming up with a superdelegate, someone from Minnesota.
Do you really think these are the people who are going to settle it for the Democrats?
Well, it's hard to know what to think.
Almost any scenario seems to be possible with the exception of the introduction of space aliens.
There is also this other tricky question of what to do about Florida and Michigan, states that were penalized by the Democrat National Committee for moving up their primaries.
The Clinton campaign is making a very strong case that they want to seat those delegates.
And the Obama campaign, of course, is saying, wait a minute, there were these rules.
We all played by them.
And now you're trying to sort of sneak one in by counting these delegates in contests - in Michigan in particular - where Obama didn't even compete.
So everybody is playing ever possible angle because it's so close.
By August someone could surely be going after the space alien caucus.
John Dickerson, Slate.com.
We'll speak again.
Thanks, Alex.
From NPR News, it's DAY TO DAY.
Drink to this, two fierce competitors in the beer market are joining forces.
Coors and Miller announced today they are forming a joint venture so they can take are on the really big brewer, Anheuser-Busch.
Amy Scott joins us from MARKETPLACE.
Amy, this is not actually a merger in some way, or is it?
Well, it is and it isn't.
It's actually a merger of the two companies' U.S.
assets.
The two parent companies in this deal are SABMiller, which is based in London, and Molson Coors, which is based in Colorado but has substantial operations in Canada.
So the deal announced today would just combine the domestic businesses - Miller Brewing Company and Coors Brewing Company.
And as you said, this deal seems to be all about competing with Anheuser-Busch, the maker of Budweiser and Michelob beers.
The company controls about 50 percent of the U.S.
market, while Miller has about 20 percent and Coors just 11 percent.
And all of these brewers have been suffering from competition lately from wine and spirits, you know, those fancy-flavored Vodkas, micro-brews.
And costs have been skyrocketing for hops and barley, and the gasoline used to transport the beer.
So by joining forces, Miller and Coors hope to save money and be in a better position to compete.
Well, I understand how that might be good for them, but doesn't this evoke some sort of anti-trust issue?
Well, I talked with Eric Shepard earlier today.
He's executive editor of the trade newsletter Beer Marketer's Insights.
And he says that is one concern.

People have been expecting this and putting these two companies together in their minds for really quite a few years, and the question in the background has always been, well, will the government allow the number two and three players to merge?
Will there be some sort of a lawsuit to try and stop it?
Certainly, I think that would be one of the hurdles they'll have to step over.
Another analyst I spoke to says, even combined, this company would only control 30 percent of the market.
And he predicts it will go through, though they may need to make some concessions.
But it's hard to say what this administration might do.
You know, the Federal Trade Commission vigorously opposed the merger of the number one and two natural food chains, Whole Foods and Wild Oats, so far the courts have refused to block that merger.
Well, they're doing this to compete with Anheuser-Busch and Budweiser.
So is it going to work?
Is Anheuser-Busch in worse position, basically, as a business because of this?
Well, it does say stiffer competition, but you know, this company has been growing too.
It's been snapping out craft breweries and various import brands.
There have also been some rumors in the market that another large brewer might buy Anheuser-Busch.
So it's likely we'll be seeing more consolidation or, at least, rumors of it if these trends continue.
